Class Method Details

+ (Object) authenticate(login_string, password)

This method tries to authenticate a user by a login_string and a password. The user is identified by the login_string (see `self.identify`).

If the given password matches the identified user, the hereby authenticated user is returned. Otherwise, this method returns `nil`.



317
318
319
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 317

def self.authenticate( login_string, password )
  UserAccount.authenticate login_string, password
end

+ (Object) find_all_by_email(email)

This method finds all users having the given email attribute. notice: case insensitive

def self.find_all_by_email( email ) # TODO: Test this; # TODO: optimize using where
  email_fields = ProfileField.where( type: "ProfileFieldTypes::Email", value: email )
  matching_users = email_fields
    .select{ |ef| ef.profileable_type == "User" }
    .collect { |ef| ef.profileable }
  return matching_users.to_a
  #User.all.select { |user| user.email && user.email.downcase == email.downcase }
end

+ (Object) find_all_by_name(name)

This method finds all users having the given name attribute. notice: case insensitive



428
429
430
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 428

def self.find_all_by_name( name ) # TODO: Test this; # TODO: optimize using where
  User.all.select { |user| user.name.downcase == name.downcase }
end

+ (Object) find_by_title(title)

This method returns the first user matching the given title.



421
422
423
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 421

def self.find_by_title( title )
  User.all.select { |user| user.title == title }.first
end

- (Object) activate_account

This method activates the user account, i.e. grants the user the right to log in.



145

147
148
149
150
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 145

def activate_account
  unless self.account
    self.account = self.build_account
    self.save
  end
end

- (Object) administrated_objects(role = :admin)

This method returns all structureable objects the user is administrator of.



382
383
384
385
386
387
388
389
390
391
392
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 382

def administrated_objects( role = :admin )
  objects = directly_administrated_objects( role )
  if objects
    objects += objects.collect do |directly_administrated_object|
      directly_administrated_object.descendants
    end.flatten
    objects
  else
    []
  end
end

- (Object) alias

The UserAlias class inherits from String, but has some more methods, e.g. a method to generate a new alias from other user attributes. To make sure that `alias` returns an object of UserAlias type, the accessor methods are overridden here.



111
112
113
114
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 111

def alias
  @alias = UserAlias.new( read_attribute( :alias ), :user => self ) unless @alias.kind_of? UserAlias
  return @alias
end

def bookmarked_objects
  self.bookmarks.collect { |bookmark| bookmark.bookmarkable }
end

- (Object) capitalize_name

This method will make the first_name and the last_name capitalized. For example:

@user = User.create( first_name: "john", last_name: "doe", ... )
@user.capitalize_name  # => "John Doe"
@user.save
@user.name  # => "John Doe"



50
51
52
53
54
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 50

def capitalize_name
  self.first_name = capitalized_name_string( self.first_name )
  self.last_name = capitalized_name_string( self.last_name )
  self.name
end

- (Object) corporations

This returns all corporations of the user. The Corporation model inherits from the Group model. corporations are child_groups of the corporations_parent_group in the DAG.

everyone
   |----- corporations_parent
   |                |---------- corporation_a      <----
   |                |                |--- ...           |--- These are corporations
   |                |---------- corporation_b      <----
   |                                 |--- ...
   |----- other_group_1
   |----- other_group_2

Warning! This method does not distinguish between regular members and guest members. If a user is only guest in a corporation, `user.corporations` WILL list this corporation.



226
227
228
229
230
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 226

def corporations
  my_corporations = ( self.ancestor_groups & Group.corporations ) if Group.corporations_parent
  my_corporations = my_corporations.collect { |group| group.becomes( Corporation ) }
  return my_corporations
end

def date_of_birth

end

- (Object) date_of_birth=(date_of_birth) 



92

# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 92

def date_of_birth=( date_of_birth )
  date_of_birth_profile_field
  @date_of_birth_profile_field ||= profile_fields.build( type: "ProfileFieldTypes::Date", label: 'date_of_birth' )
  @date_of_birth_profile_field.value = date_of_birth
end

- (Object) date_of_birth_profile_field 



97
98
99
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 97

def date_of_birth_profile_field
  @date_of_birth_profile_field ||= profile_fields.where( type: "ProfileFieldTypes::Date", label: 'date_of_birth' ).limit(1).first
end

- (Object) deactivate_account

This method deactivates the user account, i.e. destroys the associated object and prevents the user from logging in.



155
156
157
158
159
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 155

def deactivate_account
  raise "no user account exists, therefore it can't be destroyed." if not self.account
  self.account.destroy
  self.account = nil
end

- (Object) directly_administrated_objects(role = :admin)

This method returns all structureable objects the user is directly administrator of, i.e. the user is a member of the administrators group of this object.



367
368
369
370
371
372
373
374
375
376
377
378
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 367

def directly_administrated_objects( role = :admin )
  admin_group_flag = :admins_parent if role == :admin
  admin_group_flag = :main_admins_parent if role == :main_admin
  admin_groups = self.ancestor_groups.find_all_by_flag( admin_group_flag )
  if admin_groups.count > 0
    objects = admin_groups.collect do |admin_group|
      admin_group.administrated_object
    end
  else
    []
  end
end

- (Object) gender

This accessors allow to access the gender of the user rather than just asking if the user is female as allowed by the ActiveRecord accessor. (:female is a boolean column in the users table.)



75
76
77
78
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 75

def gender
  return :female if female?
  return :male
end

- (Object) gender=(new_gender) 



79
80
81
82
83
84
85
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 79

def gender=( new_gender )
  if new_gender.to_s == "female"
    self.female = true
  else
    self.female = false
  end
end

- (Object) groups

This returns all groups the user is currently a member of. In terms of the DAG model, this method returns all ancestor groups.

195
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 193

def groups

end

- (Boolean) guest_of?(group)

This method says if the user (self) is a guest of the given group.

Returns:

  • (Boolean) 


410
411
412
413
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 410

def guest_of?( group )
  return false if not group.find_guests_parent_group
  group.guests.include? self
end

- (Boolean) has_account?

A user stored in the database does not necessarily possess the right to log in, i.e. have a user account. This method allows to find out whether the user has got an active user account.

Returns:

  • (Boolean) 


138
139
140
141
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 138

def has_account?
  return true if self.account
  return false
end

- (Object) inspect

The string returned by this method represents the user in the rails console. For example, if you type `User.all` in the console, the answer would be:

User: alias_of_the_first_user, User: alias_of_the_second_user, ...


452
453
454
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 452

def inspect
  "User: " + self.alias
end

- (Boolean) main_admin_of?(structureable)

Returns:

  • (Boolean)

401
402
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 400

def main_admin_of?( structureable )
  self.administrated_objects( :main_admin ).include? structureable
end

- (Boolean) member_of?(structureable)

This method says whether the user (self) is a member of the given structureable object. This may be used to determine if the user has, for example, the read to read that object.

Returns:

  • (Boolean) 


344
345
346
347
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 344

def member_of?( structureable )
  return false if not structureable.respond_to? :descendant_users
  structureable.descendant_users.include? self
end

- (Object) memberships

Returns all UserGroupMemberships for this user. Since this is an ActiveRelation object, one can chain other conditions, like:

some_user.memberships.with_deleted
some_user.memberships.in_the_past


255
256
257
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 255

def memberships
  UserGroupMembership.find_all_by_user self
end

def name

def relationships

- (Object) role_for(structureable)

This method returns the role the user (self) has for a given structureable object.

The roles may be :member, :admin or :main_admin.



330
331
332
333
334
335
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 330

def role_for( structureable )
  return nil if not structureable.respond_to? :parent_groups
  return :main_admin if self.main_admin_of? structureable
  return :admin if self.admin_of? structureable
  return :member if self.member_of? structureable
end

- (Object) status_groups

This returns all status groups of the user, i.e. groups that represent the member status of the user in a corporation.



239
240
241
242
243
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 239

def status_groups
  self.corporations.collect do |corporation|
    corporation.status_groups
  end.flatten
end

- (Object) title

This method returns a kind of label for the user, e.g. for menu items representing the user. Use this rather than the name attribute itself, since the title method is likely to be overridden in the main application. Notice: This method does not return the academic title of the user.



67
68
69
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 67

def title
  name
end

- (Object) upcoming_events

This method lists all upcoming events of the groups the user is member of.



290
291
292
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 290

def upcoming_events
  Event.upcoming.find_all_by_groups( self.groups ).direct
end

- (Object) workflows

This method returns all workflows applicable for this user, i.e. this returns all workflows of all groups the user is a member of.



276
277
278
279
280
281
282
 
# File 'app/models/user.rb', line 276

def workflows
  my_workflows = []
  self.groups.each do |group|
    my_workflows += group.child_workflows
  end
  return my_workflows
end
